cards.notes:
!tag:Vasille
!tag:Dajaman
!rant below

honestly dajaman is one character I've always felt insecure about character-building in a cohesive and actually characterful way, partially because he's the closest I have to just being, like, a normal guy. he started out as just a generic nice himbo fighter guy, and I felt like I wasn't doing enough, and over time I started growing more and more onto him and fleshing him out more and more into his own beast, and I can only hope I've managed by this point to create something that's cohesive and doesn't just come across as "random generic thoughts incoherently put together", like I fear he has been in previous iterations. 

I think the thing that makes me feel like I'm not succeeding at creating a coherent character is that he's not defined around a single cause or event, he does have some solid motivations, but ultimately he just does what he feels like and wants to live a simple life and be happy and help people because that's what makes him more comfortable. and I think that's been a consistent thing in all my years of doing stuff with this guy. he's fluctuating and emotionally flexible, he's driven by his emotions and his instincts, and sometimes those can contradict. and maybe that's what's causing the insecurity in me. those things have consistently had a _direction_ and _limitations_ (again, a nice guy), but that sort of looser characterization made me feel like I'm not succeeding at giving him _any_ characterization. but 

of course, this rant only really makes sense to you if you're an oldhead and were around during this guy's stint on the battle boards. if you're only just now hearing about this guy, well, feel free to disregard this. but either way, if you're reading this, I just hope I've been able to do this guy justice and make, like, _a character_, with actual definable _character_.

(I can have one color pie fucky walker ult, as a treat)

A man balancing care for others with his own comfort, using violence only to end violence.
Born in brutal Jund and pained by the violence he lived among, the empathetic Dajaman was driven to make peace with the peoples of his land. When his homeland failed to change, he fled to find a new life in Bant with his mate, Rheila. For a time, they had the peaceful life they'd sought, until a near-death experience triggered both men's sparks and separated them.
On his way to find his beloved, Dajaman slowly allowed himself to be more selfish in pursuit of his own happiness. Even then, he insisted on pacifism wherever he'd go; until one day, it resulted in fatal consequences for people he'd grown attached to.
This drove Dajaman to get over himself and train in the art of battle so he could protect what he cares for, including Rheila. To reconcile the need for battle with his own comfort and compassion, he chose to practice a nonlethal fighting style meant to end battles with no lasting harm.
Once he felt he'd become capable enough, Dajaman continued his search for Rheila, still hoping to live with his mate once again.

cards.rules_text:
A healer whose devotion became his downfall.
Rheila was trained as a healer in cruel Jund from an early age; though he was taught to deaden his compassion for his thrash's sake, a strangely empathetic packmate named Dajaman opened his heart to others. The two became friends and, later, lovers, eventually leaving their clan behind to pursue an environment where their altruistic spirit could truly thrive.
After finding it in Bant, the two lived happily for some years... until one day, Dajaman seemingly died in a brutal accident [i](but in truth, merely triggered his spark)[/i]. The shock ignited Rheila in turn, hurtling him through the Eternities.
In his grief, Rheila resumed his post as a physician, devoting himself fully to never harming a single soul in honor of his seemingly dead lover's ardent pacifism. However, one patient was too wounded for any measure; in a panic, Rheila pulled the life force out of surrounding people, saving the patient but leaving his victims on the brink of death.
Convinced that he had made an irreparable mistake and failed his love, the rattled Rheila drifted into Vasille.

In the depths of Vasille, a conclave of various doctors strives to understand life itself and stops at no moral limit to do so. Their leader, Moranc, learns of Rheila's medical prowess and, taking advantage of his grief and uncertainty, lures him to the inner circle with the promise that the skills they'll learn together will ensure he'll never lose a patient, or a mate, again.
Starting from undeath and eventually graduating to live subjects, Rheila takes to studying the nature of life and death, gaining more and more insight and, with it, a sense of purpose and solace. Slowly, this blinds him to the suffering he inflicts and drowns out the pangs of guilt.
The results from one subject, Saljan, yield enough information to skyrocket Rheila's skills; however, the gruesome sight breaks through his layers of self-ignorance, making him confront what he has done and how low he has sunken. Rather than take this as a sign to amend his ways, Rheila instead concludes that nothing but his identity as a healer remains in him; with hollow resolve, he departs for the Eternities, now devoted only to his work... at all costs.

Years later, Dajaman arrives on Vasille. While its people's suffering fails to dissuade him from his own goals, he still helps some of the downtrodden.
Saljan, who has rallied other victims like him into a gang in the shadows, catches wind of Dajaman's quest and invites Dajaman to his lair. There, he shares his version of events; true, but limited.
At first, Dajaman is unable to reconcile what he hears with the noble and selfless man he loves and almost falls into despair. In this moment of weakness, Saljan orders his subjects to attack; to crush Dajaman's heart, then his body, was his plan for revenge against his tormentor all along.
This suspicious act, however, stirs doubt in Dajaman's heart; after beating off his assailants, he continues his search, certain there's more to the story. In time, he uncovers Rheila's old journal and, with it, the troubled heart behind the deeds; and with it, the grim mindset his mate has descended to.
Vindicated, relieved, but still in sorrow for Rheila's fate, Dajaman steels himself and leaves to track down his love... whatever that may mean.

A world where a civilized veneer hides a ruthless struggle for merit.
Long ago, Vasille was much like many other planes; its cities were ruled with reasonably stable democratic, its people lived in a reasonable balance with nature, and its spirituality was balanced in its worship of its inscrutable Worldsoul.
But one day, the Soul disappeared. Its people, lost in the grips of planewide existential panic, were convinced by a charismatic new political movement that the Soul was disgusted by Vasille's weakness; that its people would need to become better, more refined, more worthy of its attention for it to return.
Slowly, Vasille's culture changed. The wilds were walled off as “dangerous” and “unsightly”, and laws were bent and dissolved to favor the skilled and famous; eventually, law became something decided [i]by[/i] the skilled and famous. The people aspire for ever greater prestige, locked in endless competition and obsessed with impressing the elusive Worldsoul. Only a sense of “decorum” imposes order and restrains the plane from descending into full anarchy... but for how long?

A servant of sacred death.
From birth, Bahum was raised to worship a god of destruction and believe that, through bringing an end to that which is destined to die, death can serve as great virtue. In that cause's name, they've roamed the Multiverse, preaching the message of healing through purging all that harms a world's natural course; however, when that message has failed, they've regretfully taken on the burden of sacred destruction by their own hand. All this, they did while only thinking of their god's will.
One world, however, shook Bahum's conviction; its unnatural state was meant to protect its people, and by restoring its natural course, Bahum doomed thousands to suffering and death. Lost in despair, Bahum sought their god's counsel... only to be told that what had happened was right. Unable to accept the answer, they roamed the Eternities, only to arrive on Veronia's soil.

Veronia welcomed Bahum with open arms; its kindness soothed their soul, but they felt no closer to their answer. To what end had they done their sacred work until then? To help whom? 
Roaming the world in search of answers, Bahum was attacked; in self-defence, they used their destruction magic to kill their assailant, the first true death Veronia had seen in centuries.
This was brought to the attention of Hollmont, a queen who wanted to save Veronia from its inevitable death by overpopulation; she approached Bahum with an offer of alliance and showed them the nature of the world.
After contemplating all this, Bahum came to a conclusion; they had wanted, all along, to help people thrive in healthy worlds. And in a world like this... the only way to do that would be to save Veronia from itself. To destroy. To kill.
Armed with new purpose and Hollmont's support, Bahum took on their mantle as destroyer once again.

A world filled to bursting with life and free of danger... well, most danger.
Since it was created, Veronia has been blessed with extraordinarily abundant life force that suffuses the entire plane; thanks to its effects, no one ages, disease and wounds are healed almost instantly, crops are magically fertile, and elementals are born from the world itself. Because of this immortality, disputes are resolved through ceremonial duels, games, and other rituals.
Although lives are infinite here, things such as food and space are not; for now, the people mostly think there's no cause for concern...

An inquisitor determined to crush pride and punish weakness.
Born and raised in a cult that devotes itself to constantly testing the world's strength and will, As'hin desired to prove himself to his peers. However, affirmation never came, and his desire for it was seen as a weakness; and in his home, weakness was something to be attacked under a misguided sense that it would help.
Year by year, resentment grew inside the fox, and he sought to tear down his community for the arrogance and hypocrisy he saw inside them. Beneath suspicion due to his stature and reputation as an earnest man, As'hin studied his peers' weaknesses and prepared to exploit them, until finally, he had his chance. When he unleashed his master plan, none were spared; one by one, he mercilessly tore down everyone until they either admitted the error of hurting him or broke in utter despair. At the peak of his euphoria over his new power, As'hin's spark ignited.
Convinced that this was a reward from his god for what he'd done, the vindicated As'hin set out into the eternities to test them in his god's name.

A world that challenges its people to climb through danger to reach heaven.
Samang rises gradually towards the sky near the edges and are divided into four distinct biomes; the seas and shores of Simua at the bottom, then the lush rainforests of Pagakain, the volcanic mountains of Suglit, and the barren wastes of Pawus. Atop this final layer lies Gimpala, a mysterious paradise rumored to offer eternal life and peace.
Society centers around preparing to take the journey to Gimpala; even those who won't, like the waterbound Hantua nymphs, lend what support they can. All of Simua helps raise children and prepare supplies for the journey ahead, ascenders tackle their challenge in tightly-knit teams, and failed ascenders return to the bottom to record what they have seen for future generations. The journey is also seen as a source of self-improvement and spiritual enlightenment, whether or not it succeeds.

As'hin arrives in Samang and sees a band of warriors training to make their journey towards Gimpala. Offended and fascinated by the pride and zeal they exhibit, he chooses to follow them on their journey and torment them until they break.
As'hin sends trial after trial after the ascenders; some cannot overcome them and either retun or perish, but inspired by the determination of their leader Luningning, the rest persevere. Perplexed and enraged, As'hin confronts the team himself; however, the team makes short work of the overconfident fox, strengthened by their resolve and unity. As'han expects to perish, but Luningning extends mercy, grateful for the experiences that helped her and her team grow.
Humbled by this mercy and touched by the sight of the ascenders' determination, As'hin decides he has been misguided; his torments should be for the purpose of not only tearing down the arrogant and weak, but to find and praise the truly strong and worthy. Spurred on by this epiphany, he sets off into the Eternities once again, now with a clearer purpose.
